: Rage lifted her massive head as movement caught her attention, right 
around the borders of that big metal thing that stank of iron and those 
creatures that kept moving around it.
Almost like a huge, steel anthill.
She growled and looked down at what was left of her previous kill, now 
nothing more then a bloody spot on the ground.
Indeed, she had fed, but that was hardly enough to sustain her for long. But 
until her hunger struck again, it would not be such a bad thing to see just 
what this metal thing was.
Rage sniffed the air once; simply clearing the bloody scent of her prey from 
her gore covered snout.
Then, with a lazy growl she moved up near the metal structure, simply 
standing about 5 feet away before coming to a stop.
She extended her massive head and neck until her shout nearly touched the 
shiny surface of the Alliance base armor, the strong scent of rust and steel 
causing her to pull her head back and sneeze.
It stank!
Sure! She was used to the smell of rotting flesh and bone, but this was just 
different and she really didn�t know what to think of it.
Rage had seen others like this, huge metal mountains that prey on two legs 
exited from, but this one was just a bit smaller�a bit.
She growled as she suddenly heard strange sounds just around the bend, not 
actually realizing that the Alliance entrance was RIGHT there.
Her allosaure body shifted until her head came up right around the bend and 
against she side of the opening in the ship, not realizing that if she just 
simply looked straight down at the moment she would be staring at the top of 
Zardus� head.
However, her keen eyes fell upon something else of interest, something that 
was laying on the ground right in front of this steel thing.
It was an animal laying right in her mail view area, her shoulder brushing 
against the side of the exit as she took a few steps forward until she 
towered directly over the creature(Reptilica).
Rage turned her head and looked directly down at the animal, her whole torso 
bending down and supported by her front limbs as her snout came to rest just 
above its� head. Breathing in she took its� scent into her lungs, her 
stomach telling her that it might be a good time to feed, yet again.:
